comment._content: Time is passing ......Lovely Photo

comment._content: Not your run-of-the-mill shop back then - a lot of 'exotic' produce for sale there.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23885771@N03] Bananas, plums, lemons, and another fruit I can't quite identify...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: It's a pretty good selection considering there's a war on.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Irish Cream Toffee, 3d per slab

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I don't think they mean there's Baileys or Carolans in it.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Cube to a Cup: It is very easy to make a quick lunch if you have a tin of Armour's Bouillon Cubes at hand.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Mr Mortimer's tea is expensive compared to the Home & Colonial Stores (1/4 per lb in 1910), or is that because "there's a war on"?

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/5727931586/]

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I can't find any Mortimers in the 1911 census, in fact there are no male shopkeepers/grocers on Bridge Street at that time. There is a Robert Mortimer, retired accountant who appears in both the 1901 and 1911 censuses in Tramore and in the 1894 street directory www.lennonwylie.co.uk/1894WaterfordDirectory.htm

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think the mystery fruit are just oranges...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: I think this is on the east side of the street - for two reasons: 1. the shading on the pilasters suggests the light is coming from the right hand side (south) 2. the base of the pilaster on the left hand side is slightly taller suggesting a slope down from right to left. Looking at the 1905 OS Map there aren't many small plots on that side of the road and I reckon the shop would have been about here

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30369211@N00] Remember Cleeves Irish cream toffee slabs and the little silvered diecast hammer used to knock chunks off it....totally yummy (the toffee, not the hammer).

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: I have not found the Dog nor the dog food!

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Bulls eyes in Waterford!! .........Bulls eyes in France!  The bombardment begins: U Day, 24 June 1916. The day the battle of the Somme really began.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: And no awning to protect all the choccies from melting? "Life can be so sweet [but not] on the sunny side of the street!"
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Grab your coat and get your hat, Leave your troubles on the doorstep ... Mr Poole seems to have done a fair amount of touching-up of the negative - to hide the reflection of the building opposite, or to emphasize the fine display? I can see writing ...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03/] Not so sure about the location but I think its closer to the bridge end of Bridge Street and on the West side. The street here has a slight slope away from the Quay at this point. This is a photo taken in Bridge Street in 1952, there are two shops in the background which are similar to the one above.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] The windows in reflection match those of present building opposite.........if that makes sense!

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/] Well spotted! Yes thats the Bridge Hotel, about where my photo was taken from.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08]  Confirms your position..Who's your man?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: His name is Bill Freeman, I think he was a friend of my mother.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Why is the Special tea more than the Splendid? I would rather be splendid than just special...

comment.author: 63783963@N00
comment._content: Marvellous study. And look at those prices... I agree with brian!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Between the two Special Tea posters, does the scratched-out reflection say "OTEL"? We may be across the street from a Hotel, so. And between Splendid and Special, I think I see FAM, so it may have been a Family Hotel. Maybe Breen's? Looking at the OS 25", I think this is most likely #2 Bridge Street.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30369211@N00] I stand corrected (not for the first time! :-) ) and agree it is most likely No. 2 Bridge Street - it must have been an early morning photo with the sun coming from the northeast (it being June)

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content: Brilliant Carol.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: According to a member of the Waterford History group on Facebook, the young girls name was Mary Mortimer. She later married a Tommy Corcoran and they ran the shop and adjoining pub after her father died.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Thanks Paul. Have added Mary Mortimer and Mary Corcoran to our tags.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 67365062@N06
comment._content: I just loved this scene! So precious, a merchant and his family!
